properties.media:imagetext:
Mr. Bixby
- 2 -
September 7, 1937
* * * later * * *
pending questions, at least for the moment.
It seems to me a very wise
move to get Bond back from Hankow, as I really do not see how he can
hope to accomplish anything there under the present circumstances.
So
far the newspapers report the Chinese Government still at Nanking, but
I do not know how long they will stay there.
case, I doubt if
any good purpose would be served by Bond's following them around now.
Please let me know as soon as he gets out of China so that I can advise
Mrs. Bond,
as I violated my promise of keeping her informed because I
did not have the heart to tell her that he had gone back into China.
is nothing we can add to our advice that you take local counsel.
in Hong Kong may be
able
to advise you better than counsel in Shang-
hai could and certainly better than we can from here.
I have been working on the question of what assistance we
could properly render to the CNAC personnel now at Manila, and have ar-
ranged for their transportation sublo as far as Honolulu.
•I really
think this is all we can be expected to do, and I hope they will be sat-
isfied.
The question of employing some of them on our System is reeeiv-
ing the active attention of our Operations Department,
these things move slowly.
but as you know
I think that there is no doubt that the PAA
(Shanghai)
American personnel will be assigned to new positions with the
Systen.
I assume that the Chinese employees of PAA• (Shanghai) have been
laid off.
With regard to Miss Forbes, of course she was hired locally
and from what I have heard of the girl, I am confident she can take care
of herself.
However, it would be nice it a place could be found for her
in the PAA Manila office.
I am sure you have this in mind.
I believe there
nothing more to be said at the moment,
and I am hurrying this off, perhaps even now too late,
to catch tomorrow's
Clipper.
Very truly yours,
S. w.
Morgan
